claim: One in 10,000 people have a completely photographic memory.

supporting.text: Scientific studies on memory suggest that true photographic memory, or eidetic memory, is extremely rare, with estimates aligning closely with the claim.

attacks.text: Scientific studies on memory suggest that true photographic memory, or eidetic memory, is extremely rare, with estimates aligning closely with the claim.

The definition of 'photographic memory' varies widely across studies, making it difficult to standardize the rarity estimate.
Some researchers argue that true photographic memory may not exist at all, suggesting the claim overestimates its prevalence.
Even with self-reported data, large sample sizes can mitigate bias, lending credibility to the estimate.
Meta-analyses have attempted to standardize definitions across studies, supporting the consistency of the rarity estimate.
Case studies of individuals with exceptional memory abilities provide empirical evidence that photographic memory, while rare, does exist.
Large sample sizes do not eliminate systematic biases inherent in self-reporting, such as social desirability or misunderstanding of terms.
